options.option-description:
It is important to think about the structure of content on a page before choosing the appropriate heading. It is not about choosing one that looks nice, rather think about where the heading fits into the overall content hierarchy.

Implement headings consistently across the entire site to maximise usability.

Do not skip headings in the structure, for example going from heading 2 to heading 4.

  • There must be only one h1 element on a page: the heading University of St Andrews; h1 must not be used anywhere else on the page.
  • You may use as many h2 elements as required to denote new sections on a page.
  • You may use as many h3 to h4 elements as required to denote sub-sections of content on a page.
  • You must not use h5 or h6 elements.

• The p tag defines a paragraph.

Bold and strong

  • The HTML b element defines bold text, without any extra importance.
  • The HTML strong element defines strong text, with added semantic 'strong' importance.
  • Try to keep items in bold and strong as short as possible and refrain from writing entire sentences or paragraphs in a bold or strong typeface.
  • Bold and strong text should not be used as a substitute for headings.

Italics and emphasis

  • The HTML i element defines italic text, without any extra importance.
  • The HTML em element defines emphasised text, with added semantic importance.
  • For accessibility reasons, avoid the excessive use of italics and emphasis on the web.

options.option-description:
The abbr tag is used to define an abbreviation or an acronym. This can give useful information to browser, translation systems, and search engines.

By default in desktop browsers the abbr tag provides a tooltip.

Please note, abbr tags are redundant on mobile browsers, so it is recommended to write out abbreviations and acronyms in full, for example World Health Organisation (WHO).

body-text.text: The <abbr title='World Health Organisation'>WHO</abbr> was founded in 1948.

options.option-description:
• Blockquotes should be used when emphasising a relevant quotation in the body of text.
  • For accessibility reasons, avoid the excessive use of blockquotes.
Right-aligned blockquotes are available as a flexible alternative for pages which wrap their text fields around additional content.
